This has got me fucked up, bros.

All laws of nature can be described with differential equations. All differential equations contain initial values that inform what is measured at any point in time from those initial conditions. This means that when the universe was created, everything that would have ever happened was already determined from the beginning.

Therefore, there is no such thing as free will.

Learning this killed me. Even if science killed god, I thought at least we could take comfort in being the masters of our own destiny, but we're literally not. From the moment our brains start working the last thought we'll ever have is determined.

There is no respite in chaos theory or quantum mechanics, either. Chaos theory is just a description for hard-to-predict systems, but those systems are still determined by their initial conditions. Quantum mechanics is truly random, on the other hand, but they aren't influenced by anything else in nature. That's what makes it truly random.

People who aren't using GPT as part of their daily lives are uncreative retards - the same type of person who would spawn into minecraft in 2010 for the first time and immediately say "this is boring" without even trying to dig or do anything.

Here's some things GPT has helped me with already:
- critiquing my song lyrics, and creating song-writing exercises to help me improve.
- suggested books on niche topics I am interested in, and then contrasted those books with other books I have read, summarized those books, and provided commentary on those books
- gave me recommendations regarding the building codes in my country/province which were highly accurate

- written python code which I then used in a script to call its own API, for book-writing software
- write work emails, where I only need to feed it bullet points and it turns it into pretty languages
- simulated opinions from different perspectives on philosophical questions I'm interested in
- gave some of the best answers to "who would in in a fight" questions I've ever seen, including citing specific scenes from comic books and movies

I can't say what the future will be but this tool is insanely useful. I see a potential hell and a potential heaven in our a near future. I'm not sure anything else is possible.

>>15158527
Buy used telescopes, the optics have no moving parts so they last pretty much forever. my current telescope is a super sharp 4" refractor which was manufactured in the 1940s. buying a dob is practically heresy anyway, but if you're going to do it, you'll get more aperture per monetary unit buying used.
grinding my own optics was the most fun part of owning a dobsonian back when i had one, i liked it so much i traded my first finished mirror for a larger mirror blank before i even got started putting together the rest of the telescope.
There are a lot of people out there who decide to build a telescope for personal use and who end up as hobbyist telescope manufacturers, the optics end of astronomy is as much fun as staring through the eyepiece, you get to use a lot more math on the optical end of the business, its very engaging.
The 1970s and 1980s "gleanings for atms" columns in Sky & Telescope magazine are fill with an amazing array of excellent home made optics projects, nearly all of them better than what was on offer in the commercial market at the time.
John Dobson invented his telescope specifically with the idea of making something easy and inexpensive to build, the IQ computer clocks me at only 114 with this post and I was able to do it without a hitch. I had a buddy who built one with a folding optical tube, it could fold in half for transport and be carried like a suitcase, his own idea and build, worked perfectly, Tony was definitely higher IQ than me, I'm sorry I called him a faggot so many times.

True but I don't have a slick proof.
>inb4 why is it true
Closed subsets of S^2 are compact, so we immediately have that they have a finite number of connected components. These connected components are also all at a positive distance from each other, so we can put them in very tiny balls within the sphere. Then, we choose two connected components and argue from the cohomology group of the twice-punctured sphere.

I don't see how
>Could you remind me what it means for a curve to be projective?
There are some subleties (especially over a non-algebraically closed field [math]k[/math]), but the gist of it is that a projective variety over a field [math]k[/math] is the subset of [math]\mathbb{P}^n_k[/math] given by the vanishing of some homogeneous polynomials [math]f_1(x_0,\dots,x_n),\dots, f_m(x_0,\dots,x_n)[/math]. Remember that it makes sense for a homogeneous polynomial [math]f[/math] to say that [math]f[/math] vanishes at a point [math]P[/math] of [math]\mathbb{P}^n_k[/math]. Then, a projective curve is a curve which is projective.

Now in the case at hand the context was
>does a cubic count as an elliptic curve?
So presumably one is given a cubic polynomial in two variables, say [math]f(x,y)=3x^3+4y^3+5=0[/math], and considers its solutions in the affine plane [math]\mathbb{A}^2[/math].
What I meant to say is that we first need to "make this projective" by "adding points at infinity", by which I mean to perform the standard operation of taking [math]f(x,y)[/math], making it homogeneous ( [math]F(x,y,z)=3x^3+4y^3+5z^3[/math] ), and considering this as a projective curve in [math]\mathbb{P}^2[/math].
Note that whenever [math]z\neq 0[/math], we can normalise [math](x:y:z)=(x/z:y/z:1)[/math], and we are reduced to the "affine case". When [math]z=0[/math], we get the homogeneous equation [math]f(x,y,0)=3x^3+4y^3=0[/math], which consists of a finite number of points

>>15159464
I solved it but not elegantly. I started by rotating your triangle within the pentagon so that two of the vertices are on the midpoints of two sides of the pentagon respectively. Then there would only be one trapezoid formed within the pentagon, and the angles at its base would be equal.

Notice that the upper left vertice of your triangle is actually a pivot on the midpoint on that side of the pentagon. This means you can super impose the trapezoid in my picture on to yours (the blue line).

From there I assume there are better ways to do it. My idea ended up being turning the left and right side of the trapezoid into equations of lines and solving for the slope of the right one.
Then you can solve for the angle based on that slope, and work all the other angles out through subtraction.

>>15159464
I'm getting delta = 55.76124390703504.

delta = arccot[sin(66)*(cos(66)*(cos(54) + cos(18))+cos(54)*(cos(78)+cos(6)))/(cos(54)+cos(66)+cos(78)*cos(54)*sin(30)/sin(72))/(sin(72)*sin(36))-cot(36)]

Basically just >>15161103
I started with 6 equations (2 for each region of the pentagon).
One would use cosines to relate the lengths on the boundary to the length of the triangle edge.
One would use sines to equate the height of the altitude above the triangle edge.
You can use basic linear algebra to relate the length of the pentagon side, L, to the length of the triangle side, l.
You get l = c*L.
Then looking at the trapezoid in question, you can relate its diagonal, D, to L and l using sines.
D*sin(delta) = L*sin(72).
D*sin(alpha) = l*sin(66).
Dividing gives sin(alpha)/sin(delta) = (l/L)*sin(66)/sin(72) = c*sin(66)/sin(72).
Using alpha = delta + 36 and sine angle addition gives:
cos(36) + cot(delta)*sin(36) = c*sin(66)/sin(72).
Finally, cot(delta) = c*sin(66)/(sin(72)*sin(36)) - cot(36).

To give you a flavor of just how fucked up this is, I could tell you such Carrollian half-nonsense as
>I don't have to post the PDF file. You can recreate it telepathically by reading my mind and following
what you think is appropriate math style. Just follow these simple instructions...
Philosophically, I'm suggesting the electronic transmission of a mental printing press, a
>Gutenberg of the Mind
Turning the search for the "mystery PDF" into a code search or proof search task.
Let A be a submonoid of some free monoid and X an A-set.
Let X x| A = { (x,xa) : x <- X /\ a <- A }. Let B be a monoid and
d : X x| A -> B a map such that
>d(x,x) = 1
>d(x,xa)d(xa,xaa') = d(x,xaa')
for all x <- X and a <- A. Then d is a *differential action*.
Let A' <= A be a submonoid. The *differential subaction* for A' is the
action of A' on X plus d[|X x| A'], the restriction of d to X x| A'.
The category of differential actions is parameterized by (A,B)
In other words, a homomorphism in this category consists of
- submonoid of some free monoid A and monoid B
- A-sets X,Y and differential actions d,e
Then we should have d : X x| A -> B and e : Y x| A -> B. Now, to make this a homomorphism we need
- a map phi : X -> Y
the actual differential action homomorphism, that will hold the morphism data in this category
The homomorphism condition is phi(xa) = phi(x)a and e(phi(x),phi(xa)) = d(x,xa) for all x <- X and a <- A.
If phi is a bijection, then it is an isomorphism.
Let A' <= A be a submonoid and Y a subset of X. The *galois group* Aut[A'](X|Y) is the set of
A' differential action automorphisms phi : X -> X such that phi(x) = x for all x <- Y.

>>15147420
right regular differential action for a calc has the following meaning
We start with a submonoid of some free monoid A and a submonoid of a free monoid B.
A calc is a map e : A -> B such that
- e(1) = 1
- e(aa') <- e(a)B for all a,a' <- A.
The *shift* of the calc e by an element a <- A is the unique calc f = e^a with domain A and codomain B such that e(a)f(a') = e(aa') for all a,a' <- A.
The *right regular differential action* for the calc e consists of
- X, a copy of A, the right regular monoid action
- the differential map d(a,aa') = e^a(a').
We can then recover the original calc from the differential action as follows:
>e(a) = d(1,a)
as it is a fact that e^1 = e for all calcs e.

posts.com:
>>15160715
>But what happens when it never gets excreted?
Without function kidney, it won't get excreted, as will a myriad of other things in your bloodstream that'll end up killing you unless you get on dialysis to replace the kidney function. The kidneys aren't the only way the body elimitates medication, some are eliminated by the liver through the bile, some break down non-enzymatically, some you could technically breathe out

>I'm having a hard time wrapping my head around this. Why does it need to be reduced? Isn't the medication used in such a dose that gives it the desired effect (gets used up) and then you have to "replenish" it?
Some drugs also gets "used up", for instance by irreversibly binding to enzyms and inactivating them (like Aspirin), but other drugs only temporarily interact with whatever their target is. In general, as soon as you take medication, your body also starts metabolizing and excreting it. The dosage and dosing shedule reflects that, you want to administer it in a such a way that the concentration stays within the therapeutic range as long as necessary while avoiding side-effects/toxicity. If a patients kidney function is impaired, the elimination time for certain medications is longer and you'll reach the desired concentration with a lower dosage or get into the toxic range with a normal dosage, it's similiar for patients with imparied liver function.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15160932
>Or is my mistake, as you mentioned, thinking that all medication works by irreversibly binding to enzymes/receptors and in- or activating them? Is there medication that just flows around, occasionally doing its thing until it gets, for example, eliminated by the kidney?
Yes that's it, lots of medications work that way, they don't permanently bond, they interact in a statistical likelihood depending on their concentration, so it's in a balance like any chemical reaction. So you have a set amount of receptors that you want to target with a drug, you give a certain amount of the drug to built up a concentration of the drug in various compartments of the body that are in a chemical balance wih each other. Say one of these compartments is your intercellular space, another one is your blood and another compartment would be the molecule being bound to the receptors that you want to target. The concentration of the drug molecules in these compartments is in a constant balance. Your blood gets filtered by the kidneys, so the blood concentration of the molecules constantly decreases, which leads to molecules from the other compartments shifting into the blood and decreasing the amount of molecules that are bound to and interacting with the targeted receptor, so the effect of the drug starts wearing off. Even drugs that get used up work in that way, with the difference that the molecules that bind permanently to their target can't shift back into the other compartments, but the normal dosage you'll administer includes the anticipation that some of the drug will get filtered out before it can permanently bind to it's target. This is the general simplified gist of it

>choose x_0 in [0, 1], such that f(x_0) >= f(x) for all x in [0, 1] (exists because of the Extreme value theorem)
>choose x_1 [0, 1], such that f(x_1) < f(x_0)
>define [math]\epsilon[/math] := |f(x_0) - f(x_1)|/2
>f is continuous, therefore
[math]\exists\, \delta > 0\, \forall x \in [0, 1]: |x_{0} - x | \leq \delta \implies |f(x_{0}) - f(x)| \leq \epsilon[/math]
>this delta is the epsilon you're searching for
In case the function f is a constant polynomial, you'll have to find another solution

I absolutely hate probability, can someone help me with two assignment questions?

"At a school there are 40% girls and 60% boys. Three quarters of the girls and half of the boys have a tablet. We randomly select a student and look at the event:

J = "the student is a girl" and N = "the student has a tablet"

a) Determine the probabilities P(N | J) and P(N).
b) Determine the probability P(J | N)."


And lastly, I've done the first part of this but the second question fucks me.

"On a pin code lock, we can see that the numbers 1, 3 and 4 are heavily worn, so we assume that the pins required are made up of those three numbers"

B) If the code has four digits: how many different 4-digit codes are there, that only
using the digits 1, 3 and 4? (NOTE: make sure you actually use all three of these digits!)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15150222
b) is 1/2.
10% are girls with no tablet
30% are boys with no tablet
30% are girls with tablet
30% are boys with tablet
We sum up the latter two categories to make 60%.
So P(J | N) = 30%/60% = 1/2

B) is 36.
We know that one of the numbers is used twice, and the other two once each. So that can be any one of the three numbers.
We then find the number of possible combinations given two of one number, and one each of two other numbers. That's 4!/2! = 12.
So the answer is 12*3 = 36

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15152167
>What is the best way to debug latex?
Same way you debug any language, really:
>read the logfile (it has file extension *.log)
>delete and rebuild all intermediate files (including the index/bibliography/whatever else you happen to have)
>isolate to a minimum reproducible example (ideally with at most one instance of \usepackage)
>google the error message (or check TeX SE)
>read the package documentation and (as a last resort) source code

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15154960
Given two real numbers a and b, represent them both in binary and look for the first place where they differ (i.e. where a has digit 0 and b has digit 1). Then truncate up to that digit (i.e. get the common initial prefix of the binary representations of a and b) and you have a (dyadic) rational in betwen them.

that anon in your thread gave that correct answer.
one ground is "input" and the other is "output". its just so you can provide ground to your pump.
as for the difference between live, ground, and neutral, live is the positive voltage, ground is zero volts, and neutral is the negative voltage. imagine if you stacked two AA batteries on top of each other. measuring the voltage from the middle node (where the two batteries meet) to the top would be 1.5v, and measuring from the bottom to the middle is also 1.5v, but measuring from the bottom to the top is 3v. thats basically whats happening when youre measuring 110v across live/neutral to ground, and 220v measuring from live to neutral. they're two sin waves that are 180 degrees out of phase (flipped over, basically), so you get double the voltage. three-phase power is also common, which would be a sin wave thats 120 degrees out of phase with live, which ends up with [math]110\sqrt{3}[/math] volts, which is like 170 or something.

>>15157792
> as for the difference between live, ground, and neutral, live is the positive voltage, ground is zero volts, and neutral is the negative voltage.
This is nonsense. Neutral and ground are at roughly the same potential (they're connected together at the main board). The difference is that neutral carries the return current, ground isn't supposed to carry any current. Any exposed metal (e.g. casing) is supposed to be connected to ground so that if any live part comes into contact with exposed metal, it trips a fuse or breaker (but if there's a RCD, that will trip first).

>>15157855
> you arent gonna trip any breaker or blow a fuse if you run current to ground.
Shorting neutral to ground won't blow a fuse (but will trip a RCD). Shorting live to ground will blow a fuse for the same reason shorting live to neutral will.

> OP said it himself (in the other thread):
> > Touching one of the leads to the input neutral and the other to ground or output also gave me 110V.
That's not neutral. In the US, a 240V appliance has two live ("hot") wires (which are 180° out of phase) and no neutral. Neutral is (nominally) at ground potential, although it might differ by a volt or so due to the neutral current and Ohm's law.

Say I wish to solve the inequality [math]|x-1| + |x+1| < 2[/math]. Now, we can make use of the alternative expression for absolute values: [math]|a| = \sqrt{a^2}[/math], and what follows is:

[eqn]|x-1| + |x+1| < 2\\
\sqrt{(x-1)^2} + \sqrt{(x+1)^2} < 2\\
(x-1)^2 + 2\sqrt{(x-1)^2}\sqrt{(x+1)^2} + (x+1)^2 < 4\\
(x-1)^2 + 2(x-1)(x+1) + (x+1)^2 < 4\\
[x^2-2x+1] + 2[x^2-1] + [x^2+2x+1] <4\\
4x^2 < 4[/eqn]

which reduces to:

[eqn](x-1)(x+1) < 0[/eqn]

which is true for [math]x \in (-1,1)[/math], but clearly it does not satisfy the original question, since the LH side of the inequality above is equal to 2 in this select part of the domain (and it can easily be shown that the statement is altogether false by taking cases).

[math]x^2 + x[/math]

Basically, you want to do the following:

What I'd do in your case is look at [math]f(x) = e^{x^2} - c[/math] for [math]x \geq 0[/math] and [math]f(x) = -c[/math] for [math]x < 0[/math].

Just a quick note; the thread is still early, and others may see this.

On one hand, >>15155363 is right. The tech industry was well past due for a shakeup, so if you were thinking of being a SWE, you might wish to reconsider given the current macroeconomic climate.
On the other, as many have pointed out before, CS is not circumscribed to the tech industry. Not at all.
>the possibility of a more advanced GPT being able to code at human level im not so sure

I'm going to go out on a limb here, and say that GPT will not, within this generation, replace people doing actual CS. Sure, IT and "tech", broadly, may see a shift in how people work, with a few humans, assisted by e.g. GitHub's CoPilot tool, doing the work we see done today by overstaffed companies.
But the heavy lifting will still be done by those well qualified enough to make profound contributions a statistical regurgitator like GPT cannot.

Please consider the following example: there is work being done right now to enable reliable (but still fallible) watermarking of texts produced by ChatGPT. I won't delve into details, because who better to do so than those working on it as we speak : https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=6823 (scroll down to "My Projects at OpenAI").

This is the kind of interesting, complex and worthwhile problem you can work on if you go all the way in CS: it is a combination of theoretical CS, pure and applied mathematics, cryptography, and some practical engineering to make it all work in reality.

If you're a math grad student, the work you'll have access to are far beyond what any version of GPT in the near future can even try doing.
Unless you want to become the millionth front end developer on the framework treadmill thinking building a CRUD + REST API is CS :)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15155973
>>15156012
Systems Engineering is not "a person who deals with systems", otherwise literally everybody in society ever is a systems engineer. A systems engineer is a special kind of engineer that engineers engineers, basically an engineering project manager, that you have to hire when projects get too complex. The problem is that in complex systems not everybody that works on them understands how every other part of the system works, that's obviously impractical, so knowledge in a project is necessarily extremely fragmented and you need somebody whose job it is to make sure the system as an integrated whole meets the million requirements that go into any complex engineering project. These people, the systems engineers, have to use special methods and software to deal with the complexity to make sure the project is on the right track.

It is the least "handwavy" engineering job imaginable. DoD contractors hire them by the hundreds because you can almost never have enough of them because they're empirically guaranteed to reduce project costs. The only reason it sounds like a meme field is because "systems" is obviously a vague word, and IT technicians will call themselves "systems engineers" because they think they ""engineer"" "IT systems". They're clueless philistine idiots. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_engineering

>>15156640
>>15156939
You'll adapt and do fine even if you're super introverted but you should know that systems engineering is a way more extroverted engineering role typically than any other because you're basically a project manager, it's literally your job to communicate with all sorts of different people working on every aspect of a project, even its stakeholders (people that have some kind of vested interest in the project).

>>15155488
Hey man, I would go for the degree in econometrics (+econ), if it allows you to do the master in fin math. If you have to take measure theory /stochastic processes /pdes before being allowed in I would do so during your undergrad (if not the programme is probably bad).
The job consists mainly of modelling stuff, where a very good grasp on econometrics is indispensable. I'm talking about the fundamentals, knowing stuff like when the output of a regression is explanatory and when it is questionable. Having a good head for inferential statistics is quite rare, too. Most of the computer science stuff can be self-taught next to your studies, if you want to. The advanced mathematics is actually useless beyond getting a better head for stats / numerical methods / basic models; if your model is very complex something has likely gone wrong, as opposed to what people in '''machine learning/data science''' will tell you.
There is the added prestige of doing a difficult master, but this is only important for getting an interview. Most firms will throw your resume out if you didn't study something technical (which econ is not) or do something interesting, but fin math should be ok.
Good luck.
t. have two degrees in econometrics and stochastics myself and been to a few quant firms for competitions &c, though I would never work there.

I’m not convinced that there is self-awareness, or any other type of self-reference, for that matter. Self-reference generally results in paradox because it is simply incoherent. Likewise I can close my ears, hold my nose, etc. I can also be conscious of the fact that time passes when I’m asleep, and yet I have no memories of any conscious stimuli when I ‘m asleep. >>15156453
Not with the current generation. The issue is memory usage grows quadratically with #tokens. That's why chatGPT output is limited. There are ways to stitch it together, but it's all, everything, memory limited. That's why no video. That's why images aren't past a certain size (again, possible by stitching things, not the same)

The problem in "stitching together" code is everything must interlock perfectly - variable, function calls, operations, etc. Not easy with present tech.

5, 10 years from now, likely they're going to make memory usage most likely grow linearly (or a little more) with #tokens with corresponding hardware memory increases ~TB+. Now the AI can produce a whole movie, a whole book, a whole codebase. THEN you'll see people saying "write a frontend/backend/scraper/SQL for an engine that does XXX" and it will be written. So yes, that will be very bad for coding, but it will be bad for everything, because it also will mean "read a book", "write a book", "make a full length movie" "write a medical note", 'write a legal argument', etc etc... other more exotic stuff.. "hack this software" "make an organism genome" "propose a treatment for this disease"... "make a better CPU"... "make a better AI, and have the better AI make a better one"

The thought then is, this is all trained on prior code, so we will need coders to create new "ideas" and styles to fuel the AI. That's not a given, recently a paper was written where an AI developed a matrix multiplication algorithm that beats like 60 years of competition of academicians in terms of #operations, so humans aren't need there.

At some point someone will have a large neural net cluster, they'll be an automated AI that rewrites itself periodically. Left unattended, and connected to the internet, that's when singularity type shit will go down, best to have a non-internet connected data store

But hey even if that's the case... will need lots of people to manage the AI, QA, sysadmin, etc.

It is only a problem to mainly 2 types of people:
1. Materialists who believe that only physical things control the universe, thus directing them to the belief that there either is no consciousness or that it is somehow "physical". This gives rise to a host of misunderstandings and introduces more and more theories (like dualism etc).

2. Spiritualists who believe consciousness is a gift/some sort of first sin/natural order from a higher caliber/god/source/ what have you with the lack of a true explanation. The explanation as to the lack of explanation is usually some unmoved mover "God did it", you cannot know etc.). This gives rise to more or less the SAME theory, only with different fancy descriptions accommodating each one.

The reductionist/monist negates both of these. Both the materialist and spiritualist usually don't consider that "absence" satisfies an unmoved mover. The materialist is looking for material, something to count, locate, "have". The spiritualist does the same only with ideas/idealisms/ as they look for liberation from the material world.

The soul is nowhere specific, therefore it cannot be material or quantified (for there is no "quantity to count") or "caused" (how do you cause "not specific")?. It's not spiritual either because "no where specific" isn't omnipotence, it's not a source. It's "undefined". Not an object for you to negate. No "god"/source"/common measure or place you can ask to liberate you. You're going to be liberated no matter what you believe in by the nature of how you aren't that 'uncaused cause".

You get "half and half". Temporal "objectiveness" to then be negated by everything else "objective" chasing the same subjective absence. Nature abhors a vacuum, which means it has to constantly fill it.

>But "nothing"/absence" isn't scientific! How do we solve this problem when we have nothing to go on?
It's not an object for you to negate, but you can always treat it like a subject to synthesize.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Iq or any test only works when you're testing against a group (sample) of other people and comparing the results.
An individual score from some website is going to be inaccurate. Yes, you're being measured against their dataset, but there's no control over the circumstances of people doing the test.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15150396
It's Binary Homeworlds, in a nutshell: Upright pyramids are stars, pointing pyramids are starships of either side. Starships can take different actions depending on friendly and star colours at their location (build/move/change colour/attack). Stars are only connected (i.e. ships can move between them) when they are of different sizes. Thus you see the homeworlds consist of 2 sizes of stars, and from there you can only move to the remaining size. When 4 of a colour (including the star and both players' ships) are at a single system all pyramids of that colour are destroyed (and everything else too if the whole star is destroyed).
Ships are built from (and returned to) the shared bank which is the stash at the right. One must always take the smallest available size of a colour, but the larger sizes are obviously more powerful, so bank management is an important aspect of the game.
I found it via >>>/tg/bgg, and you can play it online on bga.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: This game I invented called empty go. Here are the rules. Two players alternate turns with black going first. Each turn consists of two phases. First the attack phase, then the maneuver phase. During the attack phase you can choose to attack any number of your opponents pieces. If you attack an enemy piece your opponents can choose to defend it. In order to defend it successfully, they must draw four straight lines, each line must connect the attacked piece to a different side of the board. This is done by pulling the twine taught above the board. In other words there must be a straight line connecting the piece to each side of the board for it to be defended. However, lines cannot pass through an enemy piece. During the maneuver phase place one piece on the board. You cannot play on top of or overlap another piece. Pieces can hang off the edge if the board as long as their center is on it. If you cannot place a piece, you lose. You can also lose by resigning.

It's exactly a white hole. That's what comes of asymptotic darkness.

The event horizon forms and you get that white hole interior. Nothing goes inside, nothing can get inside. It pushes back and inflates against the crushing gravity. The problem is that its formation is dependent on the exterior. What is the exterior? Asymptotic darkness, it is making more white holes. It becomes like a boiling foam. When I first thought of it I called it "Spacetime boiling." Occasionally I half-jokingly called it blackholeum. Only later did I learn that what I had imagined was already discovered, it was called asymptotic darkness and my only contribution was my already posited suggestion that one 'bubble' of Asymptotic darkness could be sustained by a wormhole. Specifically an Einstein-Rosen bridge. You get two black holed to entangle and you're set.

It might be from where our own universe emerges.

Scarier still is that if the universe is still expanding than the bubble of our universe is still growing and the Big bang is still happening. posts.name: Anonymous

>>15160505
Census blocks include all land in the US, so yes, it includes military bases, but even huge bases like Eglin are an insignificant percentage of the country.
Keep in mind that there are 11,155,486 census blocks and of those, 4,871,270 have zero population. In some cases this can be misleading since a large shopping mall can be a census block and have a residential population of zero even though it is heavily populated during the day. But in general, they're just rural areas. The US simply has lots of unoccupied land.

We know there is consciousness. We are conscious beings right now.

But what that means is a matter of debate and there are 3 main positions in the field.

>There is consciousness and the homunculus in our head is that consciousness. Sometimes, the homunculus is outside the body is merely part of the greater universal homunculus
Basically the old standard claim. I am the soul, the conscious being, that exists as an entity, etc Basically "intelligent design" for souls. This is basically the idealists/hindu/solipsist/christian/jewish/etc take. The standard modern religious understanding of the world. In the olden days(except Hindus), the notion of mind did not exist, what existed were the notion of "souls", hence the "intelligent design" of souls. Chalmers exists here.

>There is no consciousness, internal world of consciousness doesnt exist and there is no soul
Classical materialist position. Dennett takes this position. Its pure denial of the conscious experience such that people like Chalmers can insert in a "but how do we explain hard problem" takes.

>There is consciousness as a FUNCTION not as an entity/homunculus. Models of perception is created by the brain of which the "inner" reality is merely models and "inner reality" itself is a model as well. Frame of reference of the body in relation to the event-modeling by the brain is the nagging feeling that which leads people to believe in homunculus.
Basically the buddhist position, 2500+ years in making. The world's first manual for consciousness was written 2300 years ago by the Buddhists from which the whole notion of consciousness as we discuss is taking place today. Its a solid take which was in response to the "intelligent design" question. That dismantles the "hard question" and "qualia" nonsense but also chides the nonsensical dismissal of the materialists position of Dennett

>We need to start again value intellect
That's illegal in the USA. In the case Griggs v Duke Power, the US Supreme Court ruled that intelligence tests for employment are illegal because some races are more intelligent than others. Unable to test for general intelligence, companies turned to a proxy: the university degree.
Though not a perfect proxy for intelligence, at the time (1970s) it worked sufficiently well that most companies started adopting it as a job requirement for anything that required brain power. Since the "best jobs" now required a university degree, the government went about making sure that everyone, regardless of intelligence, could get one. This lead to credential inflation as companies increased their requirements for academic degrees while the government made getting such degrees easier and easier. In the middle of this all are universities, which are becoming insanely wealthy from this system, and workers, who have to go further and further into debt to get degrees that are proxies for a simple intelligence test.
Come up with a simple and low cost intelligence test proxy that can't be gamed and, just as importantly, won't be outlawed by the government for being a proxy, and you'll have solved the problem. This is unlikely however because the government is dead set on making sure that the dumbest people are able to access the "best jobs".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Its very distressing to know that even now we don't have good pictures of many moons in the solar system.
I think we should mass produce imaging satellites and then send orbiters to all major solar system bodies above 200km in radius (there are 80 such objects I believe).
Must be mass produced and cheap. Mostly common instruments. <100kg per orbiter.

This is our colonization list : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Solar_System_objects_by_size
Look at the piss poor images of some objects in that list. Ideally we should be having at least 5m/pixel resolution for all these objects. We can include multispectral/hyperspectral cameras too to gain insight on minerals present, other chemical weirdness, etc.
This would be a survey project - firstly there would be a lot of scientific value, and loads of data for everyone to go through. Then we could identify all interesting locations to send the next set of missions, which would contain more specialized instruments.

(If successful we can then look at surveying >100km objects, etc.)

The people that I know that have worked for Boeing have fallen into two camps. They either love it or hate it.

The ones that said they hated it worked on the commercial aircraft side and would say it is not a good place to be an engineer. They told me how the company is run by the marketing department, which makes big promises and sets short schedules, which engineering then has to scramble to try and meet. When they can't meet those expectations the blame falls on engineering. It results in over promising and underdelivering. Also the company would move people around as it saw fit, engineers were a resource, and they didn't take into account people's career goals.

The one I know who liked working at Boeing was on the space side. She worked on the starliner project. I haven't a poker with her much to know what her experience has been like. I do know she was a hard-core feminist in college and it may be that she aligns well with Boeing's corporate culture.

The X-37 made sense for the US military because they wanted to have a place to test and recover orbital hardware that wasn't public like the ISS, and they couldn't book time for that on the shuttle after its retirement. Europe wants a lot of things in space but they don't seem to have a clear understanding of why they need the things that they want, let alone a good plan to economically pursue them.

Fuck that, just make the next-gen Raptor replacement a full-flow methalox RDE. RDEs have a theoretical 20%+ ISP improvement, even if you cut that in half it would still put you squarely into the 400-420s. Basically knocking on hydrolox's door with none of the downsides. Obviously it requires a level of reliability that seems exponentially harder than standard deflagration engines, but in 5-10 years when SpaceX has mastered full-flow engines, going hard into optimizing a new combustion system seems like it'd be on the table.

>>15163346
Because the spike is substantially heavier than a sea-level nozzle, and unlike a bell engine there's no obvious taper point where most of the plumbing ends where you can attach the pivot. With an aerospike you basically have to put the entire engine with turbopumps and combustion chambers on the pivoting part. I don't know how an RDE combustion chamber would alter that but I imagine it'd make it harder, not easier.

>>15163254
They're not that heavy if you aren't using a pressurized water design (which you'd have to be retarded to consider using in space). Remember, NERVA used a reactor core with a thermal output measured in gigawatts, and only weighed a few tons.
The real mass gain comes from the low temperature radiators you need to keep the cold side of your heat engine cold. This is why I kinda like the concept of the pulsed NTR more than I like big nuclear electric, because in PNTR you are still making niggawatts of heat but 99% of it is getting dumped into super high temperature radiators with a surface area of maybe 500 square meters total, while giving you an Isp of like 10,000 (and at decent thrust). Therefore if pulsed nuclear thermal actually works, it offers comparable efficiency to electric thrusters, except at a thrust output orders of magnitude higher, which more than offsets the higher mass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15163271
Less power in electric thrusters results in less thrust, but doesn't effect Isp. Isp in electric thrusters is a function of voltage, not power. This is why ion drives can be scaled down pretty much infinitely: you can turn one watt into a gorillion volts if you wanna, you'll just directly trade off how many ions you can accelerate at once. It's kinda like how you can also go the opposite way and make an electric thruster with a high TWR but trash Isp, just by lowering the voltages and pumping more propellant through it.

>>15163598
Okay, consider this then:
Starship lets you send a probe with a plasma magnet sail and a braking stage to achieve orbit around Eris in like 5 years. In fact the transfer period is limited only by the amount of delta V in the braking stage: since a plasma magnet sail can achieve the same maximum velocities no matter what payload it's dragging if given enough time, this means the "braking stage" could be an entire fully fueled, specially constructed low mass Starship stage containing another low mass stage inside it. Sure it may take a few months to accelerate to full speed instead of a few days, but the payoff is that instead of an hour of data from one region you get years of data globally.
Of course, none of this stops you from sending ahead a vanguard high speed flyby anyway. It's just best to follow up with a slightly less high speed orbiter in my opinion.

>>15163653
>and also for colonizing the Asteroid belt and the Jovian system from Mars/Moon
>False
Explain your reasoning. From as far as I can be bothered to think, the much less intense propulsion requirements for getting into low Mars or low Lunar orbit from their respective surfaces would make everything from basic launch and orbital refilling to more advanced on-orbit fabrication of huge vehicles so much easier that taking the next steps outward becomes very feasible.
The asteroid belt should be trivial to explore and settle from Mars, not only because Mars is so close and has low gravity, but because Mars has two little moons to act as training grounds to learn to operate on an asteroid, plus they act as massive reserves of materials to build stuff from.
Jupiter would be a much bigger challenge but I'm not convinced that it would be outside the range of hydrolox vehicles built in Mars orbit. The trick would be to send out unmanned vehicles with the equipment to mine and refine water into hydrolox at one of Jupiter's outer irregular moons, then follow up with crew to set things up and get a propellant source operating in system. From that outer moon you'd then drop in towards Callisto and set up surface ISRU there as well. To do this you'd need a very big and comfy habitat that people could live in for years at a time.

>texts me virtually every hour
This is the problem with text messaging and cell phones. It used to be the case that interpersonal interaction was expected to be either in person, over a letter, over email, or through a phone call when you are at home. Meanwhile, you at the library wouldn't have any interaction with these things unless you were using one of their computers or perhaps a payphone there. You had a strict boundary of space between yourself and other people when you needed to concentrate simply by going to a location where they can't find you and all you had to do is either go to that place and most normal people wouldn't going looking for you because they could leave a message on your answering machine and then understand that you'll call them back when you're able to if you even need to talk to them. Whereas now, the expectation of instant gratification from using text messaging on cell phones at any point of time has destroyed the sense of personal space/time here as now it's expected that you can inject yourself in some way into someone's personal space/time at the click of a button and expect a response.
>How can I balance working on my thesis and textbooks with maintaining a positive relationship with my girlfriend?
Try leaving off your phone when you need to concentrate. Try setting boundaries with respect to professional time and structuring your relationship around this. There is relationship time and professional time. Professional time is separate from relationship time. Explain clearly why exactly you need these boundaries and structure; you need time to concentrate on your work and you lose concentration if you're texted regularly. If your girlfriend is remotely reasonable, she will understand and adjust her behavior.

Obviously there is a few limiting factors.

>wavelength operating range
>exposure time required for likely capture
>sensor type
>physical location of the source being exposed to open sky

I haven't had to access satellite data for a decade, so I wouldn't even know where to begin to look.

Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes, it is possible to detect isolated ionizing radiation sources on Earth using multi-spectral sensors from space. One method is to use gamma ray detectors on satellites to detect gamma rays emitted by radioactive materials. These detectors can also be equipped with multi-spectral sensors to detect different types of gamma rays, allowing for identification of specific isotopes. Another method is to use hyperspectral imaging, which can detect the specific spectral signature of radioactive materials. This technique uses a wide range of wavelengths to identify and map the location of specific materials on the ground.

Additionally, there are also other remote sensing techniques, such as Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR), and LIDAR which could be used in combination with multi-spectral sensor fusion to detect ionizing radiation sources on earth.

Generally, the more sensitive a sensor, the smaller the area it covers. You might be able to use a satellite to detect it, but it would take forever to do so because it would have to scan very small areas at a time. Probably the quickest way would be to mount a wide boom to the back of a vehicle with sensors on it to sweep the road and nearby shoulder. The radioactive item gives off enough radiation that it should be detected easy enough that way. But there might be implementation issues such as parts of the road having obstructions that the boom would hit. Still, sending out several vehicles with sensors to cover the entire route and shoulder/ditch should get the job done.
The nightmare scenario is that another vehicle ran over the radioactive item and got it stuck in its tire or knocked up into its undercarriage. In that case, it could have been transported just about anywhere and eventually fall out just about anywhere.

posts.sub: Worm rose from the sea and turned into an insect
posts.com:
Peripatus (a velvet worm) rose from the sea some 400 million years ago, to the land devoid of any insect life.

Then it evolved directly into centipedes (which further evolved into millipedes) but more importantly, some groups of velvet worm evolved into insects.

This is what happened: original state of being was multisegmented animal with multiple legs. But then due to mutation it lost all its segments except head, midsection, abdomen. It lost the legs in abdomen section (except for butterfly larvas "fake legs" that can be found anywhere around the larval form) and then the first pair of legs which were connected to the head turned into mouthparts for chewing and crushing prey.

Now it only had legs in the midsection and its always 6 legs. Similar mutation happened from centipede into millipede since millipedes have 2 leg pairs per section and centipedes have 1. Insects have 3 per section, a further evolution from millipedes, except the insects down have any other section but the midsection that can bear legs so the leg count doesnt go further up.

One segment of a millipede is the same as insects midsection. In effect millipede is constructed from dozens of midsections and one head section and one abdomen.

When I was a kid I often had this idea / thought experiment about color perception.

Consider two people looking at a red object. Their eyes perceive the light of a certain wave length and then this input is representet in their mind. We could never know because both people are referring to it in language as "red", and person B wouldn't know that other people's red looks different from his blue red.

Does this make any sense? And has science solved this or done any research on this topic? Thanks in advance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15160138
There may be some grain of truth in that. But qualia is still a philosophical idea. It rests on the assumption that there is a distinction between phenomenon and noumenon. It's a sort of neo-Kantianism where the object impresses itself upon the subject and the subject represents it in his consciousness, but unlike in Kant this representation is thought to be completely subjective.

Except in philosophy the noumenon was the main part of Kant's philosophy that was disregarded by all his successors from Hegel to Heidegger. Phenomena became the main point of study because it is the actual way we experience the world without having to refer back to some sort of contradictory unknowable noumena at all. The qualia idea is an unnecessary revival of the noumenal idea, which was abandoned by philosophers literally 2 centuries ago because of its contradictions.

For instance - if experience of phenomena is subjective (qualia), then there must be a noumenon that is ultimately unknowable to us that impresses itself upon us (Kant's thing in itself) or we would be confident that everyone has the same experience. In other words, if the noumenon were knowable, then we would be confident that the red you see is the same red that I see. But that is not what the qualia idea says, for it says all experience is subjective, ergo there must be a truly unknowable noumenon. But how then do we even know the unknowable noumenon exists? How can you know about something that is unknowable? Contradiction.

>>15161313
>there is finite space in the brain, thus [...]
This is similar to my pet thought experiment regarding the mind-body problem.
Consider a very fat man. He is literally thrice the human you are (you being a diminutive Asian woman).
By all accounts, it's seems "inaccurate" to say the Asian woman (or yourself after radical weight loss) experiences reality at only 33% the vividness (or other metric) used. As we are dealing with the matter of body, we also have to account for geometric shenanigans: nerves are mostly concentrated near the skin, and an increase to 3 times the volume (weight) does not mean your surface area has tripled as well, as it grows less fast. Say the surface has only doubled. This doesn't change the problem -- the fat man in a very real sense is "twice as conscious" as the Asian woman. Would this statement not be correct if we removed all senses BUT touch from a human?

Yet, at the same time, I also can't bring myself to say such a touch-only Helen Keller fat man is twice as conscious, because the bare fact that the Helen Keller Asian woman experiences touch already "clears a hurdle". More importantly, if she only gets touch sensations from one relatively small area, whereas the consciousness of the fat man has to "address" (or be passively aware of) a bigger area, then she might be paradoxically the being with the more significant consciousness, because a divided attention over a bigger area reduces the level of attention at every spot eventually to a minuscule quantity. Also interesting how via such arguments we almost can't help by conjure some ghostly body-independent, floating "mind" that inhabits the body as a soul. But at the same time, how can the mind NOT be this singular entity which in some sense a defined shape/circumference?

For a fully accurate comparison we'd have to use the brain directly, but my points stand even independently of facts about concrete brain architecture and how the lack of size for such impacts things.

(1/21/23)
Resolving Bell’s Inequality Paradox

Ψ^2/Ψ (Volity Theory)

Abstract: Quantum Nonlocality is currently viewed as the accepted orthodox description of how to explain the laboratory results of so-called “entangled particles” that violate the Bell inequality. This presentation provides a new theory and description of what is going on, and is able to arrive at the same calculations as traditional Quantum theory, but by using crude and basic mathematics that any person of average I.Q. can understand. The way that this is possible is by changing the paradigm of the description of the statistical results. The particles are seen to be Independent Events, and the more simple an explanation, the more likely it is to be closer to the truth of the description of reality. The new theory points in the direction of a possible Nonlocal Hidden Variable Theory. Finally, this theory proposes to serve as a possible bridge between the laboratory results and Einstein’s classically deterministic probability expectations.

After many various private calculations and versions of the same essential concepts, it is believed that the Probability differences in Bell’s Inequality can be accounted for in relation to the results in the laboratory.

We will take a look at one version of the Entanglement test. See attached photo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There is a black box, two detectors (one to the left and one to the right), two particles fired from the black box per trial (one to the left and one to the right), and a Red and Green light bulb at the end of each detector.

Each detector has 3 settings. Setting 1 on the left and setting 1 on the right would be considered the same settings. So in the above picture these would be considered different settings, just to be clear.

When the settings are the same, such as if both detectors were set at setting 1, for example, the same colored light bulbs would light up 100% of the time.

If the detectors operate at different settings, such as setting 1 on the left and setting 3 on the right (as shown in the above picture), after a collection of many results, you would get the same colored light bulbs light up only 25% of the time, and you would get differently colored light bulbs 75% of the time.

This is a conundrum as it does not align with the expected results. One would expect for the same colored light bulbs to show up 33% of the time if Einstein’s EPR were to hold true. Since it does not show up in the Laboratory, and the tests have been refined and verified on many occasions, it is concluded that Non-Local Entanglement is the accurate description of what is going on at the subatomic regime. Relativity cannot account for these results, and so a split between Local Realism and Quantum Mechanics persists in a tug of war of the accurate description of reality.

The way that we can see that 33% is calculated to be the expected results is by taking a look at a simple table:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Detector 1 and Detector 2

Settings (1-3)

(1,1) (1,2) (1,3)
(2,1) (2,2) (2,3)
(3,1) (3,2) (3,3)

These 9 results represent all of the various combinations of settings for the two detectors. Since we have established that the same settings show the same colored light bulb 100% of the time, we can remove those settings from the discussion for the time-being.

We are now only focusing on the remaining settings that provide the probability paradox of having the same colored light bulbs light up 25% of the time. We are left with the following settings:

(1,2) (1,3) (2,1) (2,3) (3,1) (3,2)

Now we need to address the light bulbs. Since each detector has 1 Red light bulb and 1 Green light bulb, we can look at all of the various possibilities:

(R,R) (R,G) (G,R) (G,G)

We can see that 2 out of the 4 possibility pairs have the same colored light bulbs:

(R,R) (G,G)

Now we will take these 2 results and divide them by the 6 above settings that are not set the same, as these 2 results out of the 6 settings is what we are focusing on.

2/6=1/3=0.33%

This is the expected probability. However, the experimental results in the lab only provide the same colored light bulb events 0.25% of the time when the settings are not set the same.

This difference is the conundrum.

It is my belief that I can account for the experimental results in the lab. The reasoning goes as follows:

When looking at the settings that aren’t the same:

(1,2) (1,3) (2,1) (2,3) (3,1) (3,2)

One needs to apply what I refer to as Absolute Independence to the various settings. You now need to look at the settings in the following way:

(1) (2) (1) (3) (2) (1) (2) (3) (3) (1) (3) (2) =12 different settings

You are adding the Independent Events together, and so you have 12. This idea is not unprecedented, as Einstein had a relatively unknown concept that he called the Separability Principle, or SEP for short, that he wanted to include in the EPR paper. This concept never made it to the paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I believe that Absolute Independence = SEP, but I came to Absolute Independence on my own, and only very recently discovered SEP.

What is ultimately being said here is that the two particles traveling to their respective detectors are ultimately Independent Events, which I call Absolute Independence. Likewise, the settings that pervade to these particles are also Independent Events.

(1,2) is not one Event or system. They are TWO Events or systems (1) (2)

So you have 12 different Independent Events, which equals 12 different Independent settings (1 setting per particle-to-detector Event).

Likewise, when looking at the light bulb results:

(R,R) (R,G) (G,R) (G,G)

One needs to apply Absolute Independence to the results. There would be 8 Independent Events of light bulbs lighting up.

(R) (R) (R) (G) (G) (R) (G) (G)

You add these together to get 8.

So now when calculating the probability of getting two of the same colored light bulbs to light up when running the trials, all Red would be one possibility and all Green would be another possibility. (1+1=2)

But remember that (Red, Red) isn’t being seen as one Event, but as TWO distinct Events. The same goes for Green.

(R) (R)
(G) (G)

Each Independent Event represents 1/8 of the total Independent Events. (Absolute Independence)

You now need to add these possibilities together where there can be two of either colored light bulb.

However, since the only way we can do that is to refer once again to two of the same colors as 1 Event, and we just established that 1+1=2 (all Red plus all Green), we now divide those 2 possibilities of the same color by the total number of Independent Events.

(R,R) (G,G) =2 Events (Waves)

Divide this by the total amount of Independent Events

(R) (R) (R) (G) (G) (R) (G) (G) =8 Events (Particles)

1/8+1/8=2/8

2/8=0.25%

What just happened is that we calculated “Waves/Particles”

This is represented as Ψ^2/Ψ

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There is no contradiction here. You are applying Wave-Particle Duality directly into the probability calculation itself.

There are many forms that you can do of this calculation. But I will only do one in this presentation in order to be as straightforward as possible.

The only thing left is to account for the difference between 33% and 25%

This is a difference of 0.0833% or 1/12

Remember that when applying Absolute Independence to the settings, you have 12.

(1)(2) (1) (3) (2) (1) (2) (3) (3) (1) (3) (2) =12 different Independent settings

Any particular pair of these settings (ex: (1,2)) would represent one ”Wave” out of the 12 ”Particles”

1/12=0.0833% (Ψ^2/Ψ)

Finally, when you add this calculation to the experimental lab results of 0.25%, you arrive at the classically expected probability results of 0.33%.

In other words:

The difference between the classically expected results and the actual lab results is Ψ^2/Ψ (Volity).

It is believed that this new insight of Volity could be applied to produce new results in the Quantum Laboratory in regards to Bell’s Inequality. I believe that the results of 0.25% could be lifted up to 0.33% and beyond in practice by applying Absolute Independence and parapsychological Psi to these tests. Those details will need to be worked out in the future, but the main point of this paper is to provide a theoretical framework for the resolution of this probability conundrum. I refer to that resolution as Volity Theory. This presentation is meant to be an introduction to this new theory.

-Thrice Hist Morphs

posts.com:
>>15143657
>proofs and spaces of proofs
There is a particular style of looking at types called Brouwer-Heyting-Kolmogorov (BHK) semantics that works a bit like that. In this style, saying “t is of type T” really mean “I have a proof that t is of type T”. Hence in this style to construct, compare, etc. types and their elements you inevitably are constructing and comparing those proofs. This “constructive” or “intuitionistic” is point of view is explicit in systems such as Coq. So this might be what your TA was talking about.
>>15143688
>There are no branches of mathematics that manipulate proofs or "spaces of proofs",
This actually was one of the claims being made to sell Homo/tranny Type Theory to normies , but mercifully, HoTT is dead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15143688
>There are no branches of mathematics that manipulate proofs
This is true. The relation of proof to math is quite strange, and doesn't go back all that long. The idea that proof and math are intimately related is likely a modernism.
Generally speaking, raw informal proofs are not considered to be "digested" enough into easily manipulatable formal parts, and students aren't taught formal proof styles like Fitch, so they have no intuition as to how formal proofs might be manipulated.
And students aren't exposed to formal inference rules, what would have to be taken as the definitions of operations that algebraically manipulate proof fragments.
As a matter of practice, no mathematician ever touches a formal proof. That work is left to logicians and computer scientists.
You could say that manipulating proofs is what mathematicians do, and it is left to logicians, philosophers, and computer scientists to contemplate what it is the mathematicians do. Although everybody agrees that mathematicians demand their work be treated as proof candidates and subjected to a review process that authenticates their work as genuine proof. But you have to do more, you have to demonstrate goodwill when it comes to the organization and presentation of your work; you can't use your work and the buzz it generates to abuse your enemies or launch a political campaign. So proof review is as much about defending the integrity of the perception of proof as it is about the formal correctness of the argument.
You can't expect me to read your proof where you define a subset of the natural numbers to be niggers.

A little meta-observation, please discuss:
(My ultimate goal is TCS, but I'm studying math.)
Certainly, math is work. It's not (just) about fun, it's mostly hard work and research-wise a lot of frustration, but anyway, I see two main end goals in going to study mathematics:
1. To learn enough to be able to participate in the creative art that is pure math and enjoy the ultimate intellectual esthetic.
2. To learn the craft for applied maths, i.e. understand e.g. PDEs and numerical maths so well you can really shine in physics research or such (or even engineering, finance, you name it).

That said, most courses I take have a flaw in these regards: they mostly make you learn theorem-proof, theorem-proof, theorem-proof ad nauseam + the additional drill of solving written-test exercises by hand. I can't help but look at my schoolmates and just see how most of them are mechanical theorem-monkeys. They are quite good at applying the admirable stack of theorems they have memorized for "theoretical applications", but there is no deeper understanding and frankly, no real skill. It's just being a nerd who does his job right. You can just tell they aren't gonna be the next Hilbert.
Anyway, it just seems like the logical conclusion of the way the courses are taught. For the first end-goal I stated, we are too focused on the definition-theorem-proof carousel that the bird-eye view of the theory is lost and mathematical creativity is stumped to the ground. For the second one, we get lost again, because how do we react when we are presented a real-life model? Will we remember Theorem #378546 along with Lemma #648364 can be applied? I doubt it.

My question is, do universities generally develop their math courses in this way as well, or is any one of you lucky enough to study in a way that gives you more than the (memorize a lot)->(pass exam)->(probably forget in five years) brainslaughter?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15151733
All the numbers I've been using have been strictly in reference to the triangular faces.
The triangle is the 2-simplex, so we can count the number of triangular faces it has by looking at the first tetrahedral number. This is the sum of the first triangular number. The first triangular number is the sum of the first integer, which is 1. Hence the triangle has 1 triangular face, which is obvious.
The tetrahedron is the 3-simplex, so we look at the second tetrahedral number. This is the sum of the first two triangular numbers. As mentioned, the first triangular number is 1. The second triangular number is the sum of the first two integers, 1+2=3. Hence the second tetrahedral number is 1+3=4, so a tetrahedron has 4 triangular faces.

In general, we can briefly summarise as follows: The kth triangular number is the sum of all integers from 1 to k. The mth tetrahedral number is the sum of the first m triangular numbers. The number of triangular faces on the n-simplex is equal to the (n-1)th tetrahedral number.
For another example, the fourth triangular number is 1+2+3+4=10, so the fourth tetrahedral number is 1+3+6+10=20. Hence the 5-simplex has 20 triangular faces.

Always rearrange the summand so that it ends with a term that explicitly depends on the index (so [math]\sum_{n=0}^\infty 2+f_n(x)[/math] in this case), then you can treat [math]\sum_{n=0}^\infty f_n(x)+2[/math] as )+2.

google everything that you need, eventually you'll figure it out. Also use overleaf for a more gentle introduction.
Things to keep in mind at first:
>the characters you'll be using the most are: curly brackets { } that work like the usual parentheses usually do in a programming language; the backslash \ is needed for almost every symbol you'd want to type; dollar signs $ $ delimit a math environment (as opposed to a text environment), write your formulas inside them. Use double dollar signs $$ $$ to display your formulas (they'll be at the center of the page, with a whole line reserved for them)
>some of the more useful stuff: ^ for exponents, _ for indices, \sum for summations, \prod for products, \frac{}{} for fractions, \to for an arrow, \implies for the "imply" arrow (there are lots of arrows but these you'll probably need the most). \gamma for lowercase gamma, \Gamma for uppercase gamma, the same holds for every greek letter (sometimes uppercase looks like a latin letter and isn't used). \mathbb{N}, \mathbb{R} for natural numbers, real numbers (and a bunch of other stuff of course, it's called blackboard bold)
>find a website which covers a bunch of other symbols, you'll learn the ones you need in no time

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There is an uncountably infinite number of real numbers.
If I take one copy of every real number, then using strict equality, every real number is equal to itself and only to itself. Therefore, I have uncountably infinitely many equivalence classes under strict equality on the reals. But this implies that by taking every real number exactly once, there must be duplicates.
QED.

Remembering things we hear while sleeping is a tricky business. Some studies have shown we can learn simple things like vocabulary words or phrases while sleeping, but more complex information like lectures or books is still a work in progress. There's also the question of whether trying to stimulate the brain to remember things while sleeping would mess with the natural functions of sleep. It's an interesting area of research with potential, but more studies are needed to really understand it.

posts.com:
Famous mathematician Benjamin Peirce taught his son, famous mathematician Charles Sanders Peirce, the powers of concentration by playing bridge with him all night. We are all living on hard mode because we don't have the basic powers of concentration, especially in this century of technology. Thus we should all be actively training our concentrative powers. It clearly worked with Peirce, so we will have to use the same method. We need an activity to train our powers of concentration, and this activity must meet 3 criteria
1. it must be scaleable, that is, the level of difficulty adjusts with your skill level. we see this in the bridge game, because at first you can just play, but as your skill increases you can count cards, calculate probabilities, get into the mind of the other player... the complexity of the game increases with your own skill level.
2. it must be inexhaustible - somewhat a corollary of the first criteria, you must not be able to learn the entire game so that it essentially becomes routine or rote. we see this with the double dummy game due to the vast amount of combinations of possible hands.
3. it must have a certain level of inherent boredom, that is, the engrossment must come from yourself and not from the game. There are plenty of video games that meet the previous two criteria, but they are not useful for training concentration because they do not require any effort to focus on. For the young Charles this boredom would come from his youth, the fact that it is an intellectual game, and from the amount of time he would have been made to play.

Now, it must be something you can do by yourself, because chances are you don't have anybody who wants to play bridge with you for hours to develop your powers of concentration. So what "game" meets all these criteria? Clearly, it is mental arithmetic. Generating random numbers, multiplying and dividing them and giving their prime factorization. This meets all three criteria to the utmost.

The brain learns by the actual performed act of learning. That is its routine equivalent to reading bites from one drive and magnetically flipping (i.e. writing) to another. There is no abstraction layer between, for both these two mechanisms.

Info download = per definition, not neuron activation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15161650
>How close are we to transferring digital knowledge to our brain via computer wires?
We haven't even made the first step towards figuring out how that could work in theory. It's most likely impossible, since no piece of knowledge is self-contained. Every word you know is part of a vast network of associations. You can't pinpoint where a particular piece of knowledge is stored in the brain, as in which neurons and neurites are involved, since it's spread all over and all the neurons you associate with it will also associated with a bunch of other things. It would involve completely decoding the brain; meanwhile neuroscientists can't even decode simple manmade microprocessors using their state-of-the-art methodology.
